as.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: used when you are comparing two people, things, situations etc
as.translation[0].definitions[0].example: Please let me know your decision as soon as possible (=as soon as you can).
His last album sold half a million copies and we hope this one will be just as (=equally) popular.
Tom’s not as old as you, is he?
an old woman with hair as white as snow
Some of the doctors are paid almost twice as much as the nurses.
We work as hard as any other team in England.
as.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: used to say what job, duty, use, or appearance someone or something has
as.translation[0].definitions[1].example: As a parent, I feel that more should be done to protect our children.
A flat stone was used as a table.
Dad dressed up as Santa Claus.
as.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: used to say what someone thinks or says a person or thing is
as.translation[0].definitions[2].example: The problem is regarded as serious.
The result of last week’s election will be seen as a victory for the right-wing government.
He’s described as being in his late teens, tall, and of slim build.
as.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: when someone was in a particular age group
as.translation[0].definitions[3].example: As a young man, Eliot had studied art in Paris.
I’ll take you to all the places I loved as a girl.
as.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: USAGE: As, like, as if/though
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0].e: Use as in comparisons in the expression as  as, with an adjective or adverb in between
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1].e: As is also used after be the same (age/size etc)
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2].e: Do not use as on its own before a noun or pronoun in comparisons Use like
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3].b: A movie is not as a book
As other people, he values his privacy
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4].e: Use as if/as though before a clause describing an imaginary situation
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[5].e: Some people also use like in this way, although this is often considered to be incorrect
They act like they own the place
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[6].e: Do not use as if/as though directly before a noun You say
as.translation[0].note_box[0].items[7].b: You treat him as if your servant
as.translation[1].definitions[0].example: They want peace as much as we do.
Helen comes to visit me as often as she can.
I can’t run as fast as I used to.
as.translation[1].definitions[1].definit: in the way that someone says or that something happens, or in the condition something is in
as.translation[1].definitions[1].example: We’d better leave things as they are until the police arrive.
The money was repaid, as promised.
He did not need to keep moving house, as his father had.
Roberta was late as usual (=in the way that she usually was).
as.translation[1].definitions[2].definit: used to say that what you are saying is already known or has been stated before
as.translation[1].definitions[2].example: David, as you know, has not been well lately.
As I explained on the phone, your request will be considered at the next meeting.
As Napoleon once said, attack is the best method of defence.
as.translation[1].definitions[3].example: I saw Peter as I was getting off the bus.
As time passed, things seemed to get worse.
Just as the two men were leaving, a message arrived.
as.translation[1].definitions[4].definit: used to state why a particular situation exists or why someone does something
as.translation[1].definitions[4].example: As it was getting late, I turned around to start for home.
We asked Philip to come with us, as he knew the road.
as.translation[1].definitions[5].example: Unlikely as it might seem, I’m tired too.
Try as she might, Sue couldn’t get the door open.
As popular as he is, the president hasn’t always managed to have his own way.
